title: Best Exercises for Lower Back Pain
author: WebMD Editorial Contributor

content: Lower back pain is a common experience for many adults. It can often result in pain, tingling, and/or numbness in the lower body. There are many causes of lower back pain, the most common include muscle strain and ligament strain.

There are two types of back pain: acute and chronic. Acute back pain lasts a few days or weeks. Most lower back pain is acute. Chronic back pain lasts longer than 12 weeks and is less common, but can have the same causes as acute back pain.

There are preventative measures you can take to relieve episodes and prevent future pains. Stretching and focused back and abdominal strengthening exercises are two of the best ways to ease lower back pain. Strong abdominal and hip flexor muscles help improve posture, and strong glutes help support the back while walking, standing, and sitting. Having strong muscles improves your mobility.

There are two types of back pain: acute and chronic. Acute back pain lasts a few days or weeks. Most lower back pain is acute. Chronic back pain lasts longer than 12 weeks and is less common, but can have the same causes as acute back pain.

There are preventative measures you can take to relieve episodes and prevent future pains. Stretching and focused back and abdominal strengthening exercises are two of the best ways to ease lower back pain. Strong abdominal and hip flexor muscles help improve posture, and strong glutes help support the back while walking, standing, and sitting. Having strong muscles improves your mobility.

sections.heading: Exercises to Help Lower Back Pain
content: The exercises below are meant to strengthen and improve flexibility in your muscles to support your lower back. Lower back pain may be recurring or a one-time experience. Doing these back-strengthening exercises daily will ease lower back pain and prevent future episodes by strengthening your abdominal, hip, and back muscles.

content_blocks.text: The exercises below are meant to strengthen and improve flexibility in your muscles to support your lower back. Lower back pain may be recurring or a one-time experience. Doing these back-strengthening exercises daily will ease lower back pain and prevent future episodes by strengthening your abdominal, hip, and back muscles.

sections.heading: Knee to Chest
content: This exercise is an easy way to warm up for your workout.
Lower Back Active Rotational Stretch
This is another easy way to get your muscles ready to move.
bullets: Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Step 2: Use both hands to pull one knee into your chest, feeling a stretch in your hip and low back. Hold 5 seconds.
Step 3: Holding your knee to chest, contract your glutes (butt) while trying to straighten your leg. Hold the contraction for 5 seconds and relax. Repeat 3-5 times.
Step 4:  Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.
You can repeat this stretch 2 to 3 times in the morning and at night.
Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Step 2: Keep your shoulders firmly on the floor, roll your bent knees to one side and hold for 1-3 seconds.

Step 3: Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side. Do this 5-10 times.  You can increase the difficulty of this move by lifting your feet off the floor while you bend your knees to the side.

content_blocks.text: This exercise is an easy way to warm up for your workout.

items: Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Step 2: Use both hands to pull one knee into your chest, feeling a stretch in your hip and low back. Hold 5 seconds.
Step 3: Holding your knee to chest, contract your glutes (butt) while trying to straighten your leg. Hold the contraction for 5 seconds and relax. Repeat 3-5 times.
Step 4:  Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.
You can repeat this stretch 2 to 3 times in the morning and at night.

content_blocks.text: Lower Back Active Rotational Stretch
This is another easy way to get your muscles ready to move.

items: Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Step 2: Keep your shoulders firmly on the floor, roll your bent knees to one side and hold for 1-3 seconds.

Step 3: Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side. Do this 5-10 times.  You can increase the difficulty of this move by lifting your feet off the floor while you bend your knees to the side.

content: You can repeat this 2 to 3 times in the morning and night.
Glute Bridges Exercise
This exercise aims to strengthen your glute and abdominal muscles .
Repeat 5-10 times, gradually building to 30 repetitions.
Lower Back Flexibility Exercise
This exercise is a low-intensity way to strengthen your lower back and abdominal muscles.
bullets: Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and your heels on the floor.

Step 2: Starting with three deep breaths, keep your shoulders and neck relaxed, tighten your abdomen and glutes, and, pushing through your heels, raise your hips upward. Be careful to not overextend your back.
Step 3: Hold the position for 1-3 seconds. Return to the starting position.
Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Step 2: Tighten your abdominal muscles like you're bracing for a punch. Hold for 5 seconds.
Step 3: Relax and flatten your back, pulling your belly button toward the floor. Hold for 5 seconds, then relax.

content_blocks.text: You can repeat this 2 to 3 times in the morning and night.
Glute Bridges Exercise
This exercise aims to strengthen your glute and abdominal muscles .

items: Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and your heels on the floor.

Step 2: Starting with three deep breaths, keep your shoulders and neck relaxed, tighten your abdomen and glutes, and, pushing through your heels, raise your hips upward. Be careful to not overextend your back.
Step 3: Hold the position for 1-3 seconds. Return to the starting position.

content_blocks.text: Repeat 5-10 times, gradually building to 30 repetitions.
Lower Back Flexibility Exercise
This exercise is a low-intensity way to strengthen your lower back and abdominal muscles.

items: Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Step 2: Tighten your abdominal muscles like you're bracing for a punch. Hold for 5 seconds.
Step 3: Relax and flatten your back, pulling your belly button toward the floor. Hold for 5 seconds, then relax.

content: Start by repeating this stretch 5 times and gradually build to 30 repetitions.
Cat and Cow
This exercise will strengthen and help alleviate stress to the lower back muscles. Doing this exercise in the morning and night will help loosen your muscles.
Seated Lower Back Rotational Stretch
When doing this exercise, be mindful to not twist too far in a way that will hurt your back.
Repeat this 1-3 times on each side daily.
bullets: Step 1: Place your hands and knees on the floor, shoulder and hip-width apart.
Step 2: Slowly arch your back and pull your abdomen up toward the ceiling. Hold 1-3 seconds.
Step 3: Slowly let your back and abdomen relax toward the floor, pushing further by pulling your shoulders back and looking up toward the ceiling. Hold for 1-3 seconds.
Step 4: Return to the starting position and repeat 5-10 times, twice a day.
Step 1: Sit on the floor or a low stool. Cross your right leg over your left one and place the other left foot flat on the floor

Step 2: Twist to the right, bracing your left arm against the outside of your right knee, then twist and stretch to the right side. Hold for 5 seconds then, maintaining your arm braced against your knee, rotate back to the left, contracting your hip and core.  Resist for 5 seconds, then relax.  Repeat 3-5 times.
Step 3: Repeat on the other side.

content_blocks.text: Start by repeating this stretch 5 times and gradually build to 30 repetitions.
Cat and Cow
This exercise will strengthen and help alleviate stress to the lower back muscles. Doing this exercise in the morning and night will help loosen your muscles.

items: Step 1: Place your hands and knees on the floor, shoulder and hip-width apart.
Step 2: Slowly arch your back and pull your abdomen up toward the ceiling. Hold 1-3 seconds.
Step 3: Slowly let your back and abdomen relax toward the floor, pushing further by pulling your shoulders back and looking up toward the ceiling. Hold for 1-3 seconds.
Step 4: Return to the starting position and repeat 5-10 times, twice a day.

Hold for 5 seconds then, maintaining your arm braced against your knee, rotate back to the left, contracting your hip and core.  Resist for 5 seconds, then relax.  Repeat 3-5 times.
Step 3: Repeat on the other side.

content_blocks.text: Repeat this 1-3 times on each side daily.

sections.heading: Safety Considerations
content: These exercises are meant to relieve not cause more lower back pain, so be mindful when moving and stop immediately if you feel shooting pains. If you do experience lower back pain when exercising, once you begin again, gradually work your way up to the previous movements. Having weak back and abdominal muscles can worsen lower back pain.

Try to avoid movements that twist or strain your back. Remember to monitor your posture and reduce stress on your back muscles, and lift smartly using your legs and keeping your back straight. In addition to exercise and muscle strengthening, other preventative measures for lower back pain include maintaining a healthy weight and giving up smoking.

sources: Harvard Health Publishing: “Stretching and strengthening are key to healing and preventing back pain.”
National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke: “Low Back Pain Fact Sheet.”
meta_description: Exercising and stretching can help relieve lower back pain. Learn the best exercises for your lower back, where to start, and how to prevent future pain.
